channel.title: Ron Paul can see the future

item.title: Ron Paul can see the future
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Again a big difference between Europe and the US. In Europe, money is needed but that’s about it. In the US, money isn’t everything either, and I guess it’s overrated. But the amount of money spent each election is staggering, and makes you wonder. That money could have been spent to create jobs, but instead it’s spent on advertising. Sure, advertisers need work, but they earn a lot already.

A politician like Newt Gingrich (I know he’s an extreme example) seems like a barbarian to most Europeans. His rhetoric might work in the US, but he wouldn’t stand a chance in most European countries. He appeals to people who think with their underbelly. We don’t need that in the 21st century. We need people who might seem boring, but who get the job done in such a way that there’s still an economy when they are done.

The US needs a completely new political system. Put limits on campaign funds, proportional representation instead of plurality voting, and less underbelly and more brain.

Read full topic
item.source: Ron Paul can see the future

item.title: Ron Paul can see the future
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:123, topic:429980”]You guys talk like people ACTUALLY decide who votes for the president.

The people’s votes go to the Electoral College, they don’t have to vote what the popular vote even was. (It gets more in depth, but oh well) The parties decide who they will elect to president with their money.[/quote]

Read full topic
item.source: Ron Paul can see the future

item.title: Ron Paul can see the future
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:123, topic:429980”]You guys talk like people ACTUALLY decide who votes for the president.

The people’s votes go to the Electoral College, they don’t have to vote what the popular vote even was. (It gets more in depth, but oh well)[/quote]
the people /do/ vote for the candidate, however it’s not a popular vote. each state is given a certain amount of votes based on population and the popular vote in the state results in those votes from the EC to the tally for the election.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Only 7m people watch fox

7/400 = all?

Believe it or not paul is winning almost all of the races right now, but the media is staying quiet. Alot of news sites have voting polls and paul is in the lead in them all.

item.source: Ron Paul can see the future

item.title: Ron Paul can see the future
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:120, topic:429980”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=532661.msg3898096#msg3898096 date=1327510404]

God loving: doesn’t count, people tend to be religious here but hardcore christians are hard to find (usually black families though, watch Tyler Perry movies)[/quote]

Compared to most Western European countries, every Christian US citizen is hardcore.

By just using the word god? Even going to church every sunday is rare here.

As much as I would personally love to see RP be the new president I just don’t see it happening.

As for the redneck comments… you guys need to actually live in a small town in the south.

or ANYWHERE in the US that isn’t a major hub.

Lol what? You think we all own ATV’s and guns outside of major hubs? Surely they can’t just be normal middle class neighborhoods?

god loving, rhetoric spewing, fox news/msnbc watching individuals.
ps: most of us is rural

God loving: doesn’t count, people tend to be religious here but hardcore christians are hard to find (usually black families though, watch Tyler Perry movies)

The minority of the US cares about politics lol. Alot of people here just flat out don’t care, or they care a bit but don’t vote.

lol@most is rural

Again, thats only the midwest US, almost every where else is not rural at all.

I have never lived in a major hub and i’ve never seen hardcore larry the cable guy chew on straw chubby overall wearing atv ridding shotgun carrying renecks that have missing teeth. They’re only in the south east (not Florida though) most Georgie, Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Tennessee and Arkansas

I’m going to only respond to the first part for now: I DID NOT AT ANY TIME MENTION ANYTHING IN REGARDS TO ATVs/GUNS.

Then define redneck.[/quote]

[quote=“t4, post:100, topic:429980”][quote author=mormonman link=topic=532661.msg3896235#msg3896235 date=1327334420]

Oh gotcha, yeah moving is not an option for me, and aren’t most country presidents/leaders christian or some sort of religious affiliation? I cant find any statistic so I could be wrong, but anyway I didn’t realize until about 2 weeks ago I agree with about all of Paul’s positions.

most are, most americans are religious fucktards - pisses me off so much.

Only most rednecks, believe it or not agnostics and atheists are very common here. The rest aren’t scientific at all and they also aren’t super religious they’re just scared by typical bullshit.

do you live in an upper class, urban bubble?

Where there are no rednecks yes

Correct, but my point is most of the US is in fact redneck. I interpreted what you said as: believe it or not we’re not all rednecks, it’s actually not as common as you think.

Define redneck. Because there are areas with lots of what I think are rednecks, but that’s only in the south east US(Louisiana, Arkansas, Alabama, etc). They are a lot more common in rural areas, not so much cities.
[/quote]
god loving, rhetoric spewing, fox news/msnbc watching individuals.

ps: most of us is rural[/quote]

Read full topic
